messageBody:
I would like to bring some clarifications on Cactus (I was the original
developer and we are now a comunity working on it :) ) :

- You need to understand clearly this stroy about client side and server
side ... Cactus uses JUnit. You run Cactus tests using any standard JUnit
test runner (the text one, the gui one, ...). JUnit is client side. We
decided to use Junit because it is the standard and already has a mechanism
for displaying and gathering the test results. JUnitEE provides a servlet
test runner (tell me if I'm wrong) that would let you see the result of your
test in a browser. Cactus is doing the same but in addition it is sending
back the results to the JUnit client so that the results can be displayed
there. This is nice because you can use any existing junit test runner and
it will work transparently. You can use the junit Ant task for example with
no modification. The idea of is to be able to do regression testing (which
is the main goal of JUnit !). That is to be able to rerun the tests and know
automatically if it fails.

- A Cactus TestCase *is* a JUnit TestCase (it inherits from it). However, it
augments it by adding 2 new methods (optional) : beginXXX() and endXXX() in
addition to the standard testXXX(). See the cactus doc for details

- Cactus let you unit test the following : Servlets, JSP, taglibs, filters
and EJB, in a consistent way.

+ much more ... ;-)

-Vincent
http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus
